info.title: How to Deploy SUSE Linux Enterprise Server with SUSE Manager on IBM PowerVM

personname.surname: Van Rompuy, Senior System Engineer and Technical Consultant, IRIS

abstract.para: The document at hand provides an overview of how to deploy SUSE Manager on IBM Power Systems. This enables you to manage and maintain your enterprise Linux system deployments across physical, virtual and cloud environments via one centralized tool. Described is a base deployment of SUSE Manager 3.1 on IBM PowerVM LPARs, including Autoinstallation, AutoYaST and Netboot Integration.

sect1.title: Installing SUSE Manager on IBM Power
sect1.para: First, you need to perform several actions related to the IBM PowerVM architecture (refer also to the IBM documentation at https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/ ):

step.para: Create a new Logical Partition (LPAR) for SUSE Manager on an IBM Power System with POWER8 or higher processors.
Configure the infrastructure for this LPAR: LAN, SAN, storage luns, zoning, etc..

Create a virtual DVD drive for this LPAR on one of the VIO servers (learn more about VIO servers here: https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/POWER8/p8hb1/p8hb1_vios_virtualioserveroverview.htm).
Add the SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 ISO files to the virtual optical device (dvd) repository on this VIO server.
Using the command cfgassist on the VIO server loads the first DVD in the virtual drive.
Activate the LPAR, enter the System Management Services (SMS) menu and choose to boot from the DVD.

sect1.title: Create and Configure the Organization
sect1.para: After the SUSE Manager setup is finished, you must create your organization on the SUSE Manager Web user interface.
Provide all the requested details including an initial administrator user and password:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Create Organization

sect1.para: Confirm with Create Organization. The following message appears on the screen:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Organization Created Successfully

sect1.para: Navigate to the Setup Wizard in the left pane:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Setup Wizard

sect1.para: Select the Organization Credentials tab:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Organization Credentials

sect1.para: Click Add a new credential:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Add Credential

sect1.para: Enter your correct organization credentials from the SCC portal and save them:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Edit Credentials

sect1.para: Now navigate to the SUSE Products tab and select the SUSE products you need. In this example, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server for SAP Applications 12 SP3 has been selected:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - SUSE Products

sect1.para: Do not forget to also check the sub-channels you need for each product:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Sub-Channels

sect1.para: When your selection is done, confirm it with Add products:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Add Products

sect1.para: Navigate to Manager Configuration in the left pane, and select Bare-metal systems as indicated below:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Bare-metal Systems

sect1.para: Now enable Bare-metal systems by clicking on the green box Enable adding to this organization:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Enable Bare-metal Systems

sect1.para: The same steps need to be performed for any additional product or version:

For all of the -ibm-dlpar-utils- child channels, deactivate the GPG check as it requires an external GPG key from IBM. To do so, navigate to Software in the left pan. Then go to Manage Software Channels and choose Overview:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Manage Software Channels

sect1.para: A list of all of the -ibm-dlpar-utils- child channels appears:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - List of Child Channels

sect1.para: Make sure the check box for Enable GPG Check is not marked:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Enable GPG Check

sect1.para: Alternatively you can download the GPG key locally and configure a local URL.

sect1.title: Creating System Groups
sect1.para: Optionally you can configure system groups to distinguish different types of systems. In this example the system groups development and production are configured.
Navigate to Systems on the left pane, and select System Groups:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - System Groups

sect1.para: Click Create Group:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Button Create Group

sect1.para: Enter the required information and confirm by clicking Create Group:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Create System Groups

sect1.para: Now you see the newly created groups:

figure.title: SUSE Manager Web UI - Show System Groups

sect1.title: Conclusion
sect1.para: With SUSE Linux Enterprise, all the tools to monitor and tune a workload are readily available. Your customers can extract the maximum performance and reliability running their applications, either on bare metal or virtualized, on the EPYC platform.
